Choose the correct letter, A, B, C or D.

Write the correct letter in boxes 27-31 on your answer sheet.

questions.question_text: The optimum amount of fluorine in fluoridated water is calculated partly according to

options.C: how many dental problems there are in the community.
options.D: how much fluorine the community chooses to have in its water.

questions.question_text: One reason given by the writer for opposing fluoridation is that

options.A: it may contribute to tooth decay.
options.B: it will be unacceptably expensive for the public.
options.C: obligatory fluoridation takes away personal freedom.
options.D: excessive fluoride could be added to the water by mistake.

questions.question_text: The writer mentions Kuhn in order to

options.A: provide a contrast with the view of Collins.
options.B: support the rational nature of scientific inquiry.
options.C: demonstrate that Kuhn did not argue his case adequately.
options.D: show that science can be influenced by non-scientific considerations.

questions.question_text: What did Sutton's research discover about earlier studies in North America?

options.A: There were failings in the way they were carried out.
options.B: The scientists involved had achieved unique results.
options.C: Proponents of fluoridation had not understood its long-term effects.
options.D: Fluoridation had a greater effect on tooth decay than previously believed.

questions.question_text: In the last paragraph, what does the writer say about scientists?

options.A: They should reveal their true motivations.
options.B: They should not decide the fluoridation policy.
options.C: They are solely concerned with scientific truths.
options.D: They cannot reach agreement on the fluoridation issue.

Many sociologists have disregarded the doubts that some scientists have concerning fluoridation.
Sutton's findings have been given insufficient attention by scientists outside of North America.
There are valid arguments on both sides of the fluoridation debate.
